Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is based on a graphic that is not directly produced by the Clinton campaign.
Exist alternative explanation: There could be alternative explanations for Sanders' stance on requiring all children to have a K-12 education, such as his belief in alternative educational systems or approaches.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Bernie Sanders does support K-12 education, as he has advocated for free public college education, which implies a foundation of K-12 education.
Understate: The claim may understate or misrepresent Sanders' position on education, as it focuses on a single aspect without considering his broader views or policies on education.
Exaggerate: There is no evidence of exaggeration in the claim as it simply states that Sanders opposes requiring all children to have a K-12 education.
Falters at times: The claim may falter at times as it relies on a graphic that may not accurately represent Sanders' stance on the issue.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that opposing "requiring all children to have a K-12 education" is a negative stance, without considering the underlying reasons or alternative approaches to education.
